replies.msg:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_nationality_law

By descent
Whether a person is a Canadian citizen by descent depends on the legislation at the time of birth. Generally speaking, any person who was born to a parent born or naturalized in Canada who has not actively renounced their Canadian citizenship is a Canadian citizen by descent (known as first generations born abroad), regardless of the time of birth. (Such renunciation of Canadian citizenship is considered valid only if it is addressed to Canadian immigration authorities.) These persons either automatically acquired Canadian citizenship at birth, or on 17 April 2009 or 11 June 2015. A small number of persons who voluntarily obtained Canadian citizenship through special grant programs before 2004 were either retroactively granted citizenship since birth or gained citizenship on the day their application was approved.

Cases for children of first generations born abroad (known as second and subsequent generations born abroad) are more complicated. For such persons, only those who were born on or before 16 April 2009 may be Canadian citizens.

Current legislation
Under Bill C-37 which went into force on 17 April 2009, every person born outside of Canada as the first generation born abroad (i.e., born to a Canadian parent who derives their citizenship from birth or naturalization in Canada) on or after 17 April 2009 is automatically a Canadian citizen by descent at birth.

The Bill also automatically granted Canadian citizenship, for the first time, to children of former Canadian citizens whose citizenship was restored on that day (which was every person who involuntarily lost Canadian citizenship under the 1947 Act). On 11 June 2015, Bill C-24 further extended the automatic grant to children of British subjects who were born or naturalized in Canada but never acquired Canadian citizenship. The acquisition of citizenship under both bills is not retroactive to birth.[18]

Children born abroad on or after 17 April 2009 to Canadian citizens by descent, and children born abroad to Canadian citizens by descent who acquired their citizenship en masse on 17 April 2009 or 11 June 2015 are subject to the first generation rule and hence are not Canadian citizens. They must go through the naturalization or adoption process to become Canadian citizens.[18]

Incorrect statement

If you are in high school, the math, physics, chem, biology science levels are recognized when transfering into canada high schools.

If you already graduated in normal university degree and works for an international firms (Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan, Citibank.. Etc) Vancouver's credit union and banks will be happy to take you.

If you have a professional degree such as nursing and doctor, I have known of two doctors that arrived in Iraq during Iraq War II, they will need to go through a government assessment to get up to date with Canadian medical system and for areas insufficient, you will need to take a few university classes and then a licensing exam.

During the mean time while getting certified, Hong kongers can rely on new policy of Student loans and working part-time in areas like senior home medical assistant. Once certified, you can return to hospital as a registered nurse.

IT and Computer programers and web designers, depends on your English skills and your IT skills. Company want to see some samples of your work.

We also need police officers as the Royal Canadian Mounted Police with full respect to human rights.

replies.msg:
First thing once arriving in Canada is to get English level up. Free classes are available to support new immigrants.

Bank teller get paid minimum wage until you become financial advisors. Minimum wage is $cad 15/ hour

Construction workers get paid ok. If you know pipe fitting, electric work.. Etc, you get paid much much more.

If you work in our container terminals as long shore man, labor and machine work, expect 80,000-100,000+ wages but very phsycal.

If you are willing to suffer long hours and much phsycal work, Canada oil fields give you two weeks work, two weeks holiday with salary of $cad 100,000+ per year. If you are willing to accept the cold and dark nights, we have diamond mines that will also pay $100,000+ per year for physical labor - two weeks work, two weeks holiday (company pays to fly you from Vancouver to work location) .

Long shore man at container terminal, oil and diamond mines are all subject to economic conditions though.

replies.msg:
Misleading statement.

Oil fields, diamond mines, long shore man all have unions. This is true.

Two of my university friends work in container terminal. One as manager and the other is a Longshore man.

For long shore man, you start as a casual worker. When work is needed, you shown up at the union hall. Names will be called by senoirty (those who have worked the most hours to those who have worked the least).

So as you gain more and more hours of work and older people retire, you gain more senioroty. From a new casual to always getting full time work (ie 100,000+ per year wages) , my friend took 3 years to reach. So during the first year, he was doing a gardening side job as well.

replies.msg:

Vancouver has very few African Americans. Toronto have a lot more.
Why are we separating the Black people in counting Canadians? We are just the same.

replies.msg:
You are mistaken.
I was trying to be polite and used "African American" instead of "black people".

quote.msg:
First thing once arriving in Canada is to get English level up. Free classes are available to support new immigrants.

Bank teller get paid minimum wage until you become financial advisors. Minimum wage is $cad 15/ hour

Construction workers get paid ok. If you know pipe fitting, electric work.. Etc, you get paid much much more.

If you work in our container terminals as long shore man, labor and machine work, expect 80,000-100,000+ wages but very phsycal.

If you are willing to suffer long hours and much phsycal work, Canada oil fields give you two weeks work, two weeks holiday with salary of $cad 100,000+ per year. If you are willing to accept the cold and dark nights, we have diamond mines that will also pay $100,000+ per year for physical labor - two weeks work, two weeks holiday (company pays to fly you from Vancouver to work location) .

Long shore man at container terminal, oil and diamond mines are all subject to economic conditions though.

Oil fields 而加 執左唔少，就算係heavy labor works, construction worker 之類 如果係high pay 嘅一定係有工會。
要入到工會先有可能有工開，但你新移民想入工會，唔係話無可能，不過係極難嗟。
唔好俾假希望人啦， 加拿大保護主義好嚴重嘅。
不過，新移民女人返而有機。

Misleading statement.

Oil fields, diamond mines, long shore man all have unions. This is true.

Two of my university friends work in container terminal. One as manager and the other is a Longshore man.

For long shore man, you start as a casual worker. When work is needed, you shown up at the union hall. Names will be called by senoirty (those who have worked the most hours to those who have worked the least).

So as you gain more and more hours of work and older people retire, you gain more senioroty. From a new casual to always getting full time work (ie 100,000+ per year wages) , my friend took 3 years to reach. So during the first year, he was doing a gardening side job as well.

replies.msg: 咪話要入工會囉，鬼唔知要儲資歷。 你無人介紹入去，form 都唔收你，仲想等job 做。。

quote.msg: 想問依家讀緊大學過到去係咪要砍掉重練？

replies.msg:
I can only speak for province of BC. Each university likely going to evacuate the courses you took.

University is normally 4 years. Many take 5 years just to have fun (including one year exchange to Europe or Asia)

The first year courses more likely than not you will get credits even if you took them in Hong Kong university because they are basic. The some of the second year and likely all the third and forth year courses, you may need to take courses in canada.

That doesn't mean the courses taken in Hong Kong's university are junk. The university here will treat it as "elective credits" thus lowering the number of courses you need to take to graduate. Depending on what you are taking, these "elective" credits can save you 4 months of school.

Also, university is a happy time. With government student loans available, you want to enjoy learning and taking what you like and upgrade your English.

You always have work. And when you are working full time, you will miss the university life. (unless it was the 理工戰役 或中大戰役)...

replies.msg:
One Indian friend is in his 30s and came to BC. He has engineering degree in India. There was no special status for him like a Hong Kongere have now.

He took two years post-degree diploma in business. Because he graduated, Canada provides 2 year college grade a 1-year work permit. His English has very heavy Indian sound. He got a job as a cellphone support staff.

After one year of work, he applies for permanent residency status with a 450 score and is in progress. During this 武漢肺炎, he didn't have work but received the Canada Emergency Response Benifit ( 紓困措施派錢) of $cad 2000 a month and BC's $cad 1000. He also getting BC government 50% off rent support
He also works as Uber-eats and skip-the-dishes driver.


My second friend is from Thailand. She went to university and entered same year as I did ( 雨傘運動 times... ) she graduated in Psychology from university. Because it's a 4 year university Canada provided a two year work permit.

She was able to become a part time social worker assistant to special needs (physical or mentally handicapped kids). She only made minimum wage... But because her work is specialized, her application to become permanent resident was quickly approved after 1.2 years working.

She now found new work in local school board to work in public school helping special need children. This work is government job with benifits and pension ( 政府長糧). Salary isn't high as Hong Kong but good enough and very good work - life balance. Everyone leaves at 3:00pm and starts at 8:30am

replies.msg:
My sister came to Canada with low level English completing grade 6.

She was able to attend a good university and in engineering. Her English level by university time still have Hong Kong sound. A few years after university graduation, while working as an engineer, and in mines, her English remains perfectly OK. It still have Hong Kong sounds.

My mother came to canada with high school education and near zero English skills. 會考肥佬. She leaned by herself and a little tutor and works in candy factory for 20+ years. Her English grammar is wrong and still have Hong Kong sound and she was able to communicate and understand conversation

However, my mother have difficulty filling government complex forms. Luckily she has us to help.

So your level of English improves as you live here. And your future children will be much more successful.

Student loans in BC contains zero interest. The federal government allows monthly repayment based on your earnings. Low wages, then smaller monthly repayments.

Because interest rate is zero, student loan debt only goes down as you repay.

One Indian friend is in his 30s and came to BC. He has engineering degree in India. There was no special status for him like a Hong Kongere have now.

He took two years post-degree diploma in business. Because he graduated, Canada provides 2 year college grade a 1-year work permit. His English has very heavy Indian sound. He got a job as a cellphone support staff.

After one year of work, he applies for permanent residency status with a 450 score and is in progress. During this 武漢肺炎, he didn't have work but received the Canada Emergency Response Benifit ( 紓困措施派錢) of $cad 2000 a month and BC's $cad 1000. He also getting BC government 50% off rent support
He also works as Uber-eats and skip-the-dishes driver.


My second friend is from Thailand. She went to university and entered same year as I did ( 雨傘運動 times... ) she graduated in Psychology from university. Because it's a 4 year university Canada provided a two year work permit.

She was able to become a part time social worker assistant to special needs (physical or mentally handicapped kids). She only made minimum wage... But because her work is specialized, her application to become permanent resident was quickly approved after 1.2 years working.

She now found new work in local school board to work in public school helping special need children. This work is government job with benifits and pension ( 政府長糧). Salary isn't high as Hong Kong but good enough and very good work - life balance. Everyone leaves at 3:00pm and starts at 8:30am

replies.msg:
Container terminal is in a town of 13000 called Prince Rupert. They constantly need people.
So one friend graduated as Math major and applied for a junior office position. Eventually got promoted to manager in the field over 6 years.

The other friend graduated in anthropology (the study of culture). He spent two years touring south America and South East asia. Then he took gardening in another university. Then he started gardening and found business is slow as summer months are busy and winter months are not. He got married and found out he needs more money as a child comes out. So he registered himself on to be labor longshore man in Prince Rupert. He was called up to work only when full time workers were injured or on long vacation or sick.

Wages are the same at (I think $45/hr). But many times, a big Costco ship arrives and it takes longer to unload and reload so there is OT (150% of wages). The terminal operating every day (before 中美貿易戰 and 武漢肺炎) so Christmas, Easter, news years their is alway OT + Double time (ie 200% of hourly wages).

So as more people retire and more shipping coming from Asia, he got more hours. He now can refuse work when he is too tired and can make more money than Manger friend.

But again... Hard work. Operating machines, and putting nails(??) into containers onto trucks and train. Maybe Hong Kong people doing container terminal will know the process..

quote.msg:
I can only speak for province of BC. Each university likely going to evacuate the courses you took.

University is normally 4 years. Many take 5 years just to have fun (including one year exchange to Europe or Asia)

The first year courses more likely than not you will get credits even if you took them in Hong Kong university because they are basic. The some of the second year and likely all the third and forth year courses, you may need to take courses in canada.

That doesn't mean the courses taken in Hong Kong's university are junk. The university here will treat it as "elective credits" thus lowering the number of courses you need to take to graduate. Depending on what you are taking, these "elective" credits can save you 4 months of school.

Also, university is a happy time. With government student loans available, you want to enjoy learning and taking what you like and upgrade your English.

You always have work. And when you are working full time, you will miss the university life. (unless it was the 理工戰役 或中大戰役)...
I’m totally fine even if i need to study again. My first priority is Canada among Five Eyes. The student loan is my biggest consideration..

Student loans in BC contains zero interest. The federal government allows monthly repayment based on your earnings. Low wages, then smaller monthly repayments.

Because interest rate is zero, student loan debt only goes down as you repay.

In BC, every public employee earning a salary over $cad75000 per year is published for citizens to see.

So I did a quick check for the City of Vancouver. How many Hong Kong Canadians are working in the government of Vancouver and making high salary of over 75000.... Turned out to be quite good numbers.

You can see the pdf published by the City of Vancouver of every employee that has salary more than $75000. See all the Hong Kong style family names - Chen, Cheng, Chiu, Chong, Lee, Leung, Tam, Wong... Etc Hong Kong style English spelling of last names.

So that is my final statement that yes... Government hires Hong Kong Canadians and professionals and these professionals make good money.

quote.msg:
Container terminal is in a town of 13000 called Prince Rupert. They constantly need people.
So one friend graduated as Math major and applied for a junior office position. Eventually got promoted to manager in the field over 6 years.

The other friend graduated in anthropology (the study of culture). He spent two years touring south America and South East asia. Then he took gardening in another university. Then he started gardening and found business is slow as summer months are busy and winter months are not. He got married and found out he needs more money as a child comes out. So he registered himself on to be labor longshore man in Prince Rupert. He was called up to work only when full time workers were injured or on long vacation or sick.

Wages are the same at (I think $45/hr). But many times, a big Costco ship arrives and it takes longer to unload and reload so there is OT (150% of wages). The terminal operating every day (before 中美貿易戰 and 武漢肺炎) so Christmas, Easter, news years their is alway OT + Double time (ie 200% of hourly wages).

So as more people retire and more shipping coming from Asia, he got more hours. He now can refuse work when he is too tired and can make more money than Manger friend.

But again... Hard work. Operating machines, and putting nails(??) into containers onto trucks and train. Maybe Hong Kong people doing container terminal will know the process..

quote.msg: Coquitlam BC好唔好住？

replies.msg:
That is basically Vancouver area.

In Hong Kong analogy, you are basically living in 油塘 . There is a sky train (like MTR) station that reaches there. It's the final /terminal station of the line.

You likely need a car to go to work.

You should be able to work anywhere in Vancouver area living in Coquitlam. If you landed a higher paying job in financial center of downtown Vancouver (like hk's central) then it will take you 45 min to reach by car.

In additional to skytrain, there is also a special a direct express train between downtown (only available morning and evening during traditional 8:30am work and 5:00pm off work) . They call it weat coast Express.

Coquitlam has more Korean style resturants. There is at least one Hong Kong level dim sum place called Grand Palace that I visit from time to time.

For car mecahnic, you can find work in any province. So for the most Hong Kong style life, you want to come to Vancouver. Car mechanics (especially if you work for Hong Kong car repair boss) have so many Hong Kong and Chinese customers, it's crazy.

For big household things like refrigerators, people seem to buy new ones than repair.

But if you know how to repair boilers/heaters, industrial equipment, all high demand.

quote.msg: 本身讀緊nursing yr1, 專材計劃過去有冇得trans cre. 同埋學生一年生活費幾多

replies.msg:
BC government tries very hard to have all university in the province to recognize credits of each other and other universities.

You will likely have classes overlap. But with Canada's program aiming for Hong Kong's 18-35 year old with student loans, you are OK.

Courses will likely have overlap. Those Hong Kong courses not used will be given credit as elective courses thus reducing the number of classes needed for graduation.

Budget:
Rent 600 per month 劏房 (share a house)
Food 400 per month (100 per week is a lot for food)
Entertainment 200 per month (simple moves, drink with friends maybe camping or hiking)

Tuition - student loans taken care

About $cad 15000 per year.

Don't forget you can do part time at $15/hr to help.

More importantly... What type of experience do you have.

If you are a social worker in Hong Kong, with a psychology or social work degree, I can see schools need some.

There is also Victim Services that need such talent in every police station to help victims.

There are other NGOs that just serve people not just Asians - salvation army, food bank.. Etc.

For car mecahnic, you can find work in any province. So for the most Hong Kong style life, you want to come to Vancouver. Car mechanics (especially if you work for Hong Kong car repair boss) have so many Hong Kong and Chinese customers, it's crazy.

For big household things like refrigerators, people seem to buy new ones than repair.

But if you know how to repair boilers/heaters, industrial equipment, all high demand.

BC government tries very hard to have all university in the province to recognize credits of each other and other universities.

You will likely have classes overlap. But with Canada's program aiming for Hong Kong's 18-35 year old with student loans, you are OK.

Courses will likely have overlap. Those Hong Kong courses not used will be given credit as elective courses thus reducing the number of classes needed for graduation.

Budget:
Rent 600 per month 劏房 (share a house)
Food 400 per month (100 per week is a lot for food)
Entertainment 200 per month (simple moves, drink with friends maybe camping or hiking)

Tuition - student loans taken care

About $cad 15000 per year.

Don't forget you can do part time at $15/hr to help.

quote.msg: 本身讀緊nursing yr1, 專材計劃過去有冇得trans cre. 同埋學生一年生活費幾多

BC government tries very hard to have all university in the province to recognize credits of each other and other universities.

You will likely have classes overlap. But with Canada's program aiming for Hong Kong's 18-35 year old with student loans, you are OK.

Courses will likely have overlap. Those Hong Kong courses not used will be given credit as elective courses thus reducing the number of classes needed for graduation.

Budget:
Rent 600 per month 劏房 (share a house)
Food 400 per month (100 per week is a lot for food)
Entertainment 200 per month (simple moves, drink with friends maybe camping or hiking)

Tuition - student loans taken care

About $cad 15000 per year.

Don't forget you can do part time at $15/hr to help.

replies.msg:
There are some additional good news.

RN nurse starts maybe $cad 45000, but you can get choose to do OT at 150% hourly wages. During this pandemic, one of my senior coworkers children has huge number of overtime and... Got Wuhan Coronavirus at hospital and had to be quarantined with salary.


One of my sisters is an an animal nurse at local animal hospital and that also have lots of OT as Canadians love their pets and pay extra attention now everyone is at home.

You also have a wife/husband, so he/she can also work at supermarket or anything part time or even do Uber-eats and Skipthedishes delivery.

The minimum wage is $15/hr so I don't see why you will fail to have a middle class life style especially every year you stay as a Registerd Nurse, your salary goes up!

Before the Coronavirus, senior Co-worker's child (nurse in Vancouver) with modest level of overtime during flu season reached 80,000 a year.

replies.msg:
I would add that our taxes is our contribution to run our system.

Our tax dollars pay for the universal health care system, and universal pension (called Old Age security similar to 生果金 of $ cad 613 per month ) for everyone over 65. There is also employment insurance in case you lose a job. Also welfare for young and old if you are poor.

In Canada, we cannot promise you will get rich easily. But we can promise that if you make an honest work and living, you will never become the old grandma/grandpa in Hong Kong picking up 紙皮箱 and begging for food. We promise you a moderate and comfortable retirement for a life of honest work.

Incorrect statement.

In BC, farms are located near the city to make it easier to transport food from farm to city.

For example, Richmond area in Vancouver (where Hong Kong people like to live), the south part of Richmond is farmland.

Surrey (a area south-east of Vancouver and 40 min drive) has strawberry farms. Langley (1hr drive south east Vancouver) has cows, pigs and chicken production.

Kelowna (a major city in middle of BC, 5 hr drive from Vancouver ) is known very famous for producing wine and growing fruits.

replies.msg:
Outside of major cities, there are far fewer Chinese people.

Yukon in the north. Saskatoon (my sister used to work in a mine there) and Regina in farming city has few Chinese/Asian people.

In my province of BC, outside of Vancouver, and capital Victoria, there aren't many Chinese/Hong Kong people. Forestry city Prince George or natural gas city of Fort St John don't have terrible Chinese food because no Chinese people there.

Nanaimo, Campbell River, Tofino (all Harbour cities) on Vancouver Island also have very few chinese. You may find some second generation chinese-Canadians that work in professional job but they speak like a western person.

Kewlona and Kamloops is wonderful wine country, mostly white people with lots of wine tasting in the summer.

There are also a number of small cites between the border of BC and province of Alberta such as Nelson, Grandforks and Cranbrooks. All small towns and very few Chinese live there.

But if your wife is an animal doctor frlm UK... You are in high demand in every animal hospital we have. Pharmacist may need recertification of some sort. Same with animal doctor. But because you're licensed in UK, I imagine the path should not be relatively easy.

replies.msg:
For universities in BC province, there is an option for mature student application. So if you have worked after high school and is 23 and older, they can apply as "mature student" to universities so you don't need high school grades.

But it is normally open for permanent resident and citizens. So under normal situations, you can work in Canada, become permanent resident and then apply to university as mature students and they ignore you high school grades.

Now, depending on our Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's policy, as it aims for Hong Konger 18-35, it is possible every Hong Konger applying can be accepted into university if 23+ years old and have work to experience. We just have to wait for more policy details.

replies.msg:
The best is Vancouver.
1) Hong Kong level Cantonese food, Bakery and Dim Sum

2) when 武漢肺炎 is over, there is daily flights to Hong Kong and its only 13hrs. Cathay Pacific even have a midnight flight so under family emergency, you can alert your boss during work hours and fly back to Hong Kong that midnight

3) 8 hrs flight to Tokyo - Hong Konger's favorite country

4) 3hrs direct flight to Disneyland's Orange County, California Airport - Hong Konger's favorite resort (similar to Toronto's 3hr flight to Orlando's Disneyworld)

5) cool summers and mild winters. Right now Vancouver is 16 degrees (Toronto is 33). Winter time we have 0-4 degrees usually (Toronto at under zero at -10).

6) we have Cantonese night classes for future children and our university have Cantonese language classes for credit (if you want children to learn Hong Kong's language and culture)

7) many Koreans and Japanese students in Vancouver to learn English (good chance to get a date!) Vancouver is the hub for ESL language learning.

CBC is correct. It's very common to have annual increases in work. My mother at candy factory got 0.50-1.20 hourly wage increases every year since she worked there. Before the minimum wage was $9/hr when she started decades ago.

Now you start at $15. My province of BC, Annual Holiday starts at 3 weeks (legal minmum is 2 weeks) and then increase to weeks after 5 years (legal minimum is 3 weeks after 5 years). Some have an extra week added if you stay loyal at the same company and max out at 6-7weeks holiday each year in their 20-30 year career.

My mom started at 2 weeks and now have 4 weeks of paid holiday.

replies.msg:
I will need to add a few things

1) Vancouver surroundings in addition to traditional UBC and SFU, there are others. BCIT for trades, Emily Carr University (for arts and design), Victoria University in Victoria city ( 1.5 hrs ferry from Vancouver), Vancouver Island University in Nanaimo (1.5hr ferry from Vancouver). There are also colleges such as Douglas College and Langara College. These are a few in Vancouver area.

2) BC province is the one of the few that provide zero interest rate student loan. So if Canada's Hong Kong rescue plan for 18-35 is to provide student loans, and easy immigration, zero interest rates is quite attractive to come to BC and study here and eventually work.

3) there is a silly argument that you can't get a job in a different location and is stuck in your university city. In a 比喻， It's like saying one grad from Chinese University at 火炭 and the other grad at Hong Kong university at 西環。So if you live in 火炭 area, you cannot apply for jobs on Hong Kong Island because your university is further away than Hong Kong university at 西環.

It's true Canada is a big county. If you are talented in successfully completing university and pretty ok social skills, you can apply and get jobs in any city inside Canada. Most employers see you grad is a known Canadian university (we don't have 野雞大學), and you did well in interview, you're hired with 3 months trial.

The only advantage of location is this. You normally try to apply for jobs in your home city before another province, so local employers have an advantage of hiring the fresh grads and new talent.

Usually as a new grad, you will accept a good job even if it requires you to move. My first job after grad is in... Japan (for fun) and then a more serious government work in small town of 13000 people in the north. It took a few years to make it back to Vancouver area.

One of my sister grad as engineer at University of Waterloo and needed to move to Saskatoon to a work in a mine.

4) Canada and USA are two different countries. Graduate in Canada gives you work permit in Canada (not in USA). If you are extremely talented, US companies will hire you and apply for work permit for you. You do not simply walk accross the US border and start working for a company. It's lots of work for a mid size company to apply for a work permit for a Canadian but they will do it if your job is high demand - doctors, nurses, animal doctors/nurses, health care field and hospital support staff.

There is always hope you might really end up working in USA. One of my sisters fell in love with a Chinese-American. She has a degree in commerce in a small university in Canada. They met online by playing a game called "world of warcraft" and met in real life (apparently such love relationships is more common than you think) . They married and instead of the guy moving to Canada, my sister moved to USA. She was able to work in New York and then now works in California. The degree and work experience in Canada was no problem and was recognized in USA.

5) once the Canadian rescue hong kong package is out, and it's indeed student loans + immigration. Then likely you are paying CANADIAN DOMESTIC TUITION. Canadian universities are subsidized by government, so domestic tuition is about 33% of international rates. So International student pay $300, domestic students only pay $100 in tuition. So under this scheme and the quality of education, unless you are going to Harvard or Yale or those Ivy Leagues, it crazy to abandon the Canadian university for USA ones and pay International tuition rates.

一樣
想重新來過

Teachers require special destination. A professional teacher in Hong Kong I imagine you can get your creditial evaluated. Then BC government can see what courses are missing and then you can go to UBC to complete recertification - choice of elementary school option or secondary school Option.

Once you recertified, you should be able to teach elementary school or secondary school. Maybe your experience will best be use to teach public school's ESL and Chinese beginner level 10, level 11, and level 12.

Public school teachers get paid 10 months and 2 months no-pay summer holiday - unless you are principal or need to do office work or you choose to teach summer classes (for failing students) . But the 10 paid months can be distributed to be paid over 12 months. Salary isn't very high but 兩袖清風. The most valuable is teacher's pension 長糧. You will get upon retirement.


Alternatively, there are ESL schools in BC that you can temporarily make a living while you get recertified.

Public school teachers get paid 10 months and 2 months no-pay summer holiday - unless you are principal or need to do office work or you choose to teach summer classes (for failing students) . But the 10 paid months can be distributed to be paid over 12 months. Salary isn't very high but 兩袖清風. The most valuable is teacher's pension 長糧. You will get upon retirement.


Alternatively, there are ESL schools in BC that you can temporarily make a living while you get recertified.

I will need to add a few things

1) Vancouver surroundings in addition to traditional UBC and SFU, there are others. BCIT for trades, Emily Carr University (for arts and design), Victoria University in Victoria city ( 1.5 hrs ferry from Vancouver), Vancouver Island University in Nanaimo (1.5hr ferry from Vancouver). There are also colleges such as Douglas College and Langara College. These are a few in Vancouver area.

2) BC province is the one of the few that provide zero interest rate student loan. So if Canada's Hong Kong rescue plan for 18-35 is to provide student loans, and easy immigration, zero interest rates is quite attractive to come to BC and study here and eventually work.

3) there is a silly argument that you can't get a job in a different location and is stuck in your university city. In a 比喻， It's like saying one grad from Chinese University at 火炭 and the other grad at Hong Kong university at 西環。So if you live in 火炭 area, you cannot apply for jobs on Hong Kong Island because your university is further away than Hong Kong university at 西環.

It's true Canada is a big county. If you are talented in successfully completing university and pretty ok social skills, you can apply and get jobs in any city inside Canada. Most employers see you grad is a known Canadian university (we don't have 野雞大學), and you did well in interview, you're hired with 3 months trial.

The only advantage of location is this. You normally try to apply for jobs in your home city before another province, so local employers have an advantage of hiring the fresh grads and new talent.

Usually as a new grad, you will accept a good job even if it requires you to move. My first job after grad is in... Japan (for fun) and then a more serious government work in small town of 13000 people in the north. It took a few years to make it back to Vancouver area.

One of my sister grad as engineer at University of Waterloo and needed to move to Saskatoon to a work in a mine.

4) Canada and USA are two different countries. Graduate in Canada gives you work permit in Canada (not in USA). If you are extremely talented, US companies will hire you and apply for work permit for you. You do not simply walk accross the US border and start working for a company. It's lots of work for a mid size company to apply for a work permit for a Canadian but they will do it if your job is high demand - doctors, nurses, animal doctors/nurses, health care field and hospital support staff.

There is always hope you might really end up working in USA. One of my sisters fell in love with a Chinese-American. She has a degree in commerce in a small university in Canada. They met online by playing a game called "world of warcraft" and met in real life (apparently such love relationships is more common than you think) . They married and instead of the guy moving to Canada, my sister moved to USA. She was able to work in New York and then now works in California. The degree and work experience in Canada was no problem and was recognized in USA.

5) once the Canadian rescue hong kong package is out, and it's indeed student loans + immigration. Then likely you are paying CANADIAN DOMESTIC TUITION. Canadian universities are subsidized by government, so domestic tuition is about 33% of international rates. So International student pay $300, domestic students only pay $100 in tuition. So under this scheme and the quality of education, unless you are going to Harvard or Yale or those Ivy Leagues, it crazy to abandon the Canadian university for USA ones and pay International tuition rates.

The best is Vancouver.
1) Hong Kong level Cantonese food, Bakery and Dim Sum

2) when 武漢肺炎 is over, there is daily flights to Hong Kong and its only 13hrs. Cathay Pacific even have a midnight flight so under family emergency, you can alert your boss during work hours and fly back to Hong Kong that midnight

3) 8 hrs flight to Tokyo - Hong Konger's favorite country

4) 3hrs direct flight to Disneyland's Orange County, California Airport - Hong Konger's favorite resort (similar to Toronto's 3hr flight to Orlando's Disneyworld)

5) cool summers and mild winters. Right now Vancouver is 16 degrees (Toronto is 33). Winter time we have 0-4 degrees usually (Toronto at under zero at -10).

6) we have Cantonese night classes for future children and our university have Cantonese language classes for credit (if you want children to learn Hong Kong's language and culture)

7) many Koreans and Japanese students in Vancouver to learn English (good chance to get a date!) Vancouver is the hub for ESL language learning.
How abt earthquakes?

replies.msg:
https://globalnews.ca/news/5464403/bc-earthquake-the-big-one/
According to data from Earthquakes Canada, there are approximately 200 seismometers across Canada that are used to sense and measure earthquakes.

Earthquakes as strong as magnitude 9 strike along this fault line every 200 to 800 years, triggering giant tsunamis, according to a fact sheet from Natural Resources Canada.

The last destructive earthquake happened on Jan. 27, 1700, and experts say it is “inevitable” that another one will hit the coast. It’s predicted the quake could take place along the Cascadia Subduction Zone, a 1,000-kilometre fault line that runs from northern Vancouver Island to Northern California.

WATCH: Ground split by fissures near epicentre of Southern California earthquake


0:37
Ground split by fissures near epicentre of southern California earthquake
Ground split by fissures near epicentre of southern California earthquake
“In my world, I say, ‘Wow, we’re kind of due for one,'” Clague said.

Earthquakes are linked to the moving of tectonic plates that lie directly beneath the surface of the earth, which makes them incredibly difficult to forecast.

READ MORE: ‘Inevitable’ 9.0 earthquake, tsunami will hit Canada’s West Coast: expert

A 6.3-magnitude quake struck about 211 km off the coast of Bella Bella, B.C., around 9:30 p.m. on Wednesday, according to Earthquakes Canada. (The U.S. Geological Survey measured it as 6.2). Three smaller quakes occurred nearby on Friday.

Off the coast of B.C., earthquakes are not at all uncommon.

“That’s a real hotspot. It’s probably the most active little chunk of real estate in Canada as far as earthquakes go,” Clague explained.

“We’ve had about 30 earthquakes of magnitude 5 or larger in the last three or four decades in that area, and that’s just a function of the geology of that particular place beneath the ocean floor.“

B.C. QUAKES


In addition, Clague says it’s common for earthquakes to come in clusters, known as aftershocks.

“That’s just a result of the main shore destabilizing Earth’s crust and leading to readjustments in the form of typically smaller earthquakes, although not always smaller,” Clague said.

While a handful of aftershocks are common after a serious earthquake, Californians have experienced over 200. However, Clague notes that B.C. and California are located near different tectonic plates, meaning the events are likely unrelated.

READ MORE: 5.6 magnitude earthquake strikes near Bella Bella, B.C., no reports of damage

Whether it’s the Big One or the smaller earthquakes British Columbians are used to, the provincial government has taken many steps to prepare, including retrofitting seismometers.

replies.msg:
Those interested in medical field have choices.

Medical doctor, dentists, animal doctor (most difficult to get in), nurses, massage therapist, chiropractors, physiotherapist, nurses, and animal nurses to say a few.

Surprisingly, the easiest is animal nurse and the hardest is animal doctor (because we only have one university to train animal doctors).

If medical doctor is too hard (and I have friend that fail to become one), human nurse (male/female both ok) is also a good choice.

If you are willing to move out of a big city to attend university for nursing, you can go to small universities like University of Northern BC to become a nurse (easier to get in). A registered nurse can graduate in any university in my province of BC. And the nurse license is valid anywhere in Canada (with transfer) and reconized in USA. So it's perfectly OK to go to a very rural university and become a nurse, work for 5 years to have students loans forgiven, and then return to big city to work for long term.

replies.msg:
Incorrect statement.

Canada's retirement is much more 全面 than Hong Kong. It's made of 3 supporting pillars.

1) Canada Pension Plan 國家管理長糧
2) Old Age security (Old Age Supplement if you are really poor ) 生果金 + 貧窮人綜援
3) company pension or Company Registered Retirement Saving Plan and Tax Free Saving Account 工司長糧式工作強積金，＋ 自己 免稅儲蓄戶口

Even if you have zero savings in 3....

A lifetime of honest work, you will have 有尊嚴的退休生活, and no need to 執紙皮箱.



For every job you work including fast food joints, there your employer and yourself will contribute to Canada Pension Plan 國家級長糧. Normally it is about 5% of your salary and employer pays 5% to match. When you retire at 65, you will get Canada pension plan payment until you die.

replies.msg:
My sisters all start work in private companies after graduated from college and university. The white collar work normally provide 3 weeks of vacation to start. By 5th year of working, they have 4 weeks vacation.

My mother started in a candy factory. She recieved public holidays + 2 weeks vacation (legal minimum) for fist 5 years. Then 6th year she recieved 3 weeks vacation. Then 20th year, she revived 4 weeks vacation.

For my Co-worker's wife who worked in supermarket Thrifty Foods for 20 years, she has 6 weeks vacation.

Government work depends on province and city. Normal Rules is year 1-5 is 3 weeks vacation. Then year 6-10, 4 weeks vacation. Then year 11-15, 5 weeks. And then 16-20 is 6 weeks vacation. If you get promoted in management in city government, instead of OT, you for example get 7 weeks vacation.
輕輕推

replies.msg:
Few things.

技工 = electrian? Pipe fitters? Mecahnic? Car mechanic? Truck driver? Industrial machine repair?

If that is the case, we need you. If you enjoy working on your hands, BCIT is all about working with hands - trades type job.

It's best to learn a little on these trades in Hong Kong first. For example, let say you learned to be an electrician 電工 in Hong Kong and have worked 2 years. Then you move to my province of BC. Here's the plan in your head

1) get BC student loans and go to BCIT. Get your English level up. Because you have experience, becoming a certified electrician through BCIT program should not be too difficult. Work part time for a master electrian. Also go for driving school (lots of Cantonese driving instructors) and get a driver license. This will be a busy 2-3 years. You can only rent near campus and you probably can only use public transport.

2) you grad from BCIT and become Canadian certified electrician. You now need to choose where to work. Work is plentiful for electrician especially when there is lots of construction work in Vancouver due to very high housing prices. You should be earning $cad 25 and rising to $cad 40/ hour over next few years. The more you work, the more you get paid because work seems unlimited. If Vancouver had bad economy, you can travel to oil fields in Alberta to work as electrician and they pay 300% more. During these 5 years, you should be able to buy a car.

3) while you are single, you do not give up your advantage of being mobile (ie taking any job in any area within driving distance). So buying an apartment (樓) is terrible idea. But you will have some savings in prepare for such a future.

4) 8 years since you moved to BC, the student loans are half-way paid. Your English level is good enough to communicate. You fell in love. You got married. Now.. Two people with similar income levels, now you can start looking where to buy an apartment.

5) currently Vancouver area in the outer area like Surrey (similar to 香港新界) is about $cad 400,000. But you can live in other cities and travel to Vancouver for the food. For example, you and live in Nanaimo, BC or Victoria, BC. The apartment can drop to 250,000-350,000 in those surrounding areas. and take water plane ($cad 100 per way) to fly 20-30 minutes to downtown Vancouver for lunch and all the Hong kong experience. Two people can afford this.

6) 13-15 years in. You should be making easily $40 per hour and lots and lots amount of work especially when you speak English and Cantonese and Mandarin (for the mainland China customers). Summer time will be extremely crazy and money keep flowing like never before. You have a child baby and want it to grow up and at least know a little Cantonese to order dim sum. So you move to Vancouver and buy a $cad 500,000 apartment.

The story continues and you probably will use the western way and hire a financial planner (advisor) to guide you to retirement.

replies.msg:
I hope it we will return to normal and not have second wave of the 武漢肺炎. But if we do get a second wave this fall, it can be reasonable to expect the results of 447 in May would happen again.

That being said. Canadian government is suppose to have a rescue package for Hong Kongers to make immigration easier as well as attract those 18-35 year old. So I am optimistic on the situation.

Overall, I am indeed quite optimistic on the success of Canada and USA. Many poor Chinese arrived in USA through family ties immigrants (not skills) and their children born and grew up here are very successful.

In university, I have international students friends from Thailand and India that have not as good English as professionals of Hong Kong still manage to immigrate and find a middle class life so far.

Some mainland Chinese international students that I used to be friends with but all left after my support of Hong Kong's Umbrella Movement in university. These mainland Chinese students don't have the same western thinking as Hong Kongers nor the same level of critical skills or political understanding of democracy and human rights. They even have worst English than professional Hong Kong people. Yet they too found jobs upon university graduation and seem to be able to apply for permanent residency. (I exlude 官二代 types).

So I think Hong Konger needs to have more 自信 in your own abilities. This international rescue effort is gained because of all the sacrifices of everyone last year in 反送中 and even before in the 雨傘運動. You don't get opportunities like this often and I truly think Hong Kongers should take use these 逃生門 to save yourselves and to build another Hong Kong community overseas to keep part of our culture there. (and provide funding for Hong Kong's 國際線)

replies.msg:
標籤： Apartment 公寓 Condo 選擇
【大紀元記者馮閱多倫多編譯報導】夏天是公寓出租的旺季。在長長的選擇列表上，哪個性價比更高？哪個更適合自己？您要考慮地理位置、室內佈局、附屬設施、交通狀況等等因素。因為這些方面不可能都能得到滿足，所以往往難以做出選擇。
單從附屬設施來看，房價不同設施也會有不同，衡量起來會比較容易一些。Condo通常價格較高，但包含的設施也會更多。不少Condo擁有洗衣機、健身房，電影院、宴會廳等，可能會讓你願意花更多的錢來享受這些便捷。總之，選擇之前一定要審視一下你是否會使用Condo所提供的諸多服務，這種生活方式是否更適合自己？
孰優孰劣
Conrad Rygier是多倫多By The Park地產公司的銷售員，他說：「4月份到6月份是多市公寓出租的旺季。在這裡提醒租客在正式租房前要考慮多方面因素。」
「如果一個人的財政緊張，apartment將是個更好的選擇。如果收入良好，那麼就可以考慮離工作地點近的Condo，通常來說Condo都建在市中心，這樣您可以走路或騎車去上班。」
Condo裡的洗衣房也讓您免去搬運衣物到投幣洗衣房的麻煩。而Condo裡的健身房也比每月花費高達$60的私人俱樂部更安靜、更方便。很多Condo裡還有電影院和宴會廳。您也大可不必和朋友花錢在外面看電影或聚會。
MoneySense雜誌比較了不同的價格後發現：卡爾加里的Condo均價只比apartment高$42；而多倫多則因為附屬的健身房、洗衣房和娛樂設施等將近高出$200；在蒙特利爾，Condo均價比apartment高$310；而溫哥華，根據居住地不同，價格高出$104至$183不等。
為了能享受這些附加的服務設施，首先要確保你目前的收入是否能承受得起。加拿大住房與抵押機構（CHMC)建議人們的租房及其他房屋花銷不能超過稅前收入的30%。
Rygier說：「我認為花銷應該具有一定的經濟基礎，應在自己的承受能力範圍之內消費。如果租房花銷過大會有很大的風險。一旦您失業了又沒有足夠的積蓄該怎麼辦？」
2011年的CHMC報告指出，加拿大的住房數量不斷減少，房租也隨之升高。
加拿大統計局報告說2012年加拿大大城市的空房率是2.8%。其中卡爾加里最低，為1.3%。2010年4月至2011年4月，多倫多的空房率從2.7%下降到1.6%。與此同時，溫哥華從2.5%上漲到2.8%。蒙特利爾從2.8%下降到2.5%。
租房注意什麼
Rygier提供了一些能減輕租房焦慮的方法：
1. 確定你搬遷的日子並提前通知房東
2. 確定新房的地址
3. 確定你的信用良好
Rygier說：「大部分房東會要求你提供最近的信用記錄。在多倫多，TransUnion和Equifax是兩個最常見的信用記錄提供機構。您可以網上申請，一般價格在$15到$23。租房之前一定要確保你手頭有足夠的錢，因為您需要繳納第一個月和最後一個月的房租。」
看房時如有疑問，一定要多問。而且要認真計算自己每個月的花銷，尤其是有關公寓設施的費用。通常來說，一些私人公寓無需繳納水費，但需自付電費。而有些Condo所提供的服務設施也無限制條件。具體到自己租住的公寓一定要諮詢清楚，做到心中有數。
一旦你簽了合同之後，記住無論您的新家多麼好，也會有不可避免的損壞。更換或修補有可能是一筆很大的費用。此時，租客保險可為您節省很大一筆費用。◇

replies.msg:
在外國，「Condo」常被認定為產權分售公寓或私人公寓，而每戶都有獨立產權，在加拿大、美國是很常見的；而「Apartment」通常被認定為出租公寓，顧名思義，其在絕大多數情況下是用來出租而非出售。

「Co-ops」涉公司產權

而公寓還有「Co-ops」，常被認定為「共同產權」公寓，而「Co-ops」實際上是指公司所持有的公寓；當公司出售公寓，業主購買的並非此公寓的產權，而是購買該公司股份，即股權交易。而當中也有分兩種，一種只是轉讓該公寓的長期租賃權，但卻沒有轉讓業權，而另一種則是業權和長期租賃權一起轉讓。

產權不同

私人公寓（Condo）和出租用的公寓（Apartment）的主要區別在於產權不同。一整棟物業中，「Condo」是每戶業主各擁有自己的產權，每個單位都是由不同的業主擁有；而「Apartment」是指整幢樓由一個業主擁有，這種物業各單位可以分開出租，但卻不能單獨出售，售賣時必須只能整體一棟出售。

Apartment受中國人歡迎

「Apartment」在外國總體來說是很受中國人歡迎的，因為中國人喜歡利用槓桿來進行投資物業，當支付了30-50%的首期後，就可以擁有整幢物業的產權，用每月租金來還房屋貸款。只要找到位置好，位於學校周邊、市中心，或公共交通站點8分鐘步行距離以內的公寓，必定具有很好的投資價值的，往往都能獲得較高的租金回報率及一定的升值空間。

replies.msg:
其實租condo or apartment, 產權根本唔關你事。
1. apartment 通常無獨立洗乾衣機，要share用
2. Apartment 由公司擁有，通常有加租限制同埋佢唔可以趕你走
Condo 都有加租限制，但業主可以格硬犯法地趕你走
3. Condo 通常有少少facilities like gym room , party room or swimming pool
4. 綜合以上原因，condo 貴 d apartment 平d
5. 由於apartment 租平d, 所以收入低比例大，會有bed bug 或者衛生情況較差

有巴打提議開group,大家點睇，想fb,tg 開定點，我見到依家fb都有一啲加拿大香咁群組，不過有啲就成日罵戰，有啲經營得麻麻，無乜人睇。我嘅初步構思係整一個港人互助群組，其他一概唔講，由落地到日常生活，甚至如果之後有人招聘，開鋪想推廣，都會做埋。之如會唔會有長期計劃，（尤其我非常希望可以做到有一定規模，等如果黎緊局勢更差，會有大量人黎，我希望可以做好一個平台嘅角色，幫到大家），就要視乎之後點樣。總言之，初步概念係一個港人互助群組，如果有任何意見，歡迎大家提出。
